How do we simplify say that we would want to be able to dynamically scale up and scale down and dynamically distribute load among the active instances. How do we do that. We want to have great visibility into what's happening behind the scenes with each of these microservices a simple request might involve 10 microservices how do I determine which microservice was caused for a defect. How do I know if all my microservices are up and running. And how do I prevent one microservice being down taking down the entire application. How do I build fault tolerance into my microservices.

Spring Cloud

In this section we will discuss about the challenges with microservice architecture. In this section we would introduce you to spring cloud and we'd talk about various components under the umbrella of spring cloud which help us to provide solutions to the challenges we discussed. Let's get started. If you go to the home page of spring cloud which is cloud.spring.io it says spring cloud provides tools to quickly build some of the common patterns in distributed systems to the typical problems which are present for distributed systems in the cloud spring cloud provides a range of solutions. The most important thing that you need to understand is spring cloud is not really one project as such. There are a wide variety of projects under the umbrella of spring cloud on the spring cloud homepage. If you scroll down further you'll be able to see huge variety of projects which are related to spring cloud. One of the important projects in spring cloud is spring cloud Netflix. Netflix was one of the organizations which started playing around with the microservices architecture very early. There are a wide range of components that Netflix has Open-Source under the project spring Cloud Netflix later in this course. We'd be talking about a couple of them as well. Eureka Hystrix and so on other than spring cloud Netflix. There are a wide range of projects under the umbrella of spring cloud.

Some of them are spring cloud config which is to provide a centralized configuration management spring cloud bus. This enables the microservices and the infrastructure components things like config server things like API gateway to talk to each other in this course we'd be using the Finchley M2. release of spring cloud. Now let's take a quick look at the challenges which we discussed earlier and the projects in spring cloud that provide solutions to those challenges. One of the challenges we talked about earlier was configuration management. We talked about the fact that there would be multiple microservices multiple environments for each of these microservices and multiple instances in many of those environments. This would mean that there is a lot of configuration for these microservices that the operations team needs to manage. Spring cloud config server provides an approach where you can store all configuration for all the different environment of all the microservices in a Git repository. So you can store all the configuration for different environments of different microservices in just one place in a centralized location and spring cloud config server can be used to expose that configuration to all the microservices. This helps us to keep the configuration in one place and that makes it very easy to maintain the configuration for all the MicroServices.

The next challenge we talked about was the dynamic scale up and scale down. In the example you are looking at there is MicroService is called currency calculation service which is talking to the currency exchange service. As you can see in the diagram there are multiple instances of the currency exchange service and it's possible that at any point in time new instances can be added in or removed out. And we would want the currency calculations that we'd want to be able to distribute the load between all the instances of the currency exchange service. Who would want to be able to dynamically check what are the available instances of the currency exchange service and make sure that the load is distributed among all of them. The solution which we would be discussing in this course would be using a naming server which is Eureka. So all the instances of all MicroServices would register with the naming server. So the naming server has two important features. One is service registration so all microservices. Can register with the microservicew one the second one is service discovery. So in this example the currency calculation service can ask the Eureka naming server Hey naming server give me the current instances of currency exchange service and the naming service would provide those URLs to the currency calculations. this helps to establish dynamic relationship between the currency calculation service and the instances of the currency exchange service.

We will use Ribbon for client side load balancing. That means the currency calculation service will host ribbon and it would make sure that the load is evenly distributed among the existing instances that it gets from the naming server we'll also use Feign in the currency calculation service as a mechanism to write simple RESTful clients the solutions for visibility and monitoring are the zipkin distributing Tracing Server. We would use Spring cloud Sloat to assign ID to request across multiple components and we would use the Zipkin distributed tracing to trace a request across multiple components.

One of the important things about microservices is these microservices have a lot of common features. For example logging security analytics and things like that you don't want to implement all these common features in every microservice. API Gateways provide great solutions to these kind of challenges. We will use a Netflix Zuel API gateway in this could.

We will also implement fault tolerance using hystrix if a service is down. Hystrix help us to configure a default response.

Advantage of MicroServices

In this section we would be discussing about some of the advantages of microServices. Architecture is the most important advantage of the MicroServices architecture is that it enables you to adapt new technology and processes very easy. When they build applications as a combination of microservices which can communicate with each other using simple messages each of these microservices can be built in different technologies. Typical more nolet applications people would not have that flexibility. For example Microservice one might be java MicroService two might be Nodejs Microservice three might be written in Kotlin and tomorrow there might be a language X Y Z which is really doing well and which provides a lot of benefits to you and you can easily create a micro service in that specific language. And also for the new Microservices that we create we can bring in new processors as well. The other important advantage of Microservices is Dynamic scaling consider an online shopping application like Amazon. They don't really have the same amount of load or same amount of traffic or same amount of users throughout the year especially during the holiday season. The load on the application will be a lot and during the rest of the year there might not be so much load during the Black Friday there might be a huge amount of load. If your microServices are cloud enabled they can scale dynamically and you can procure hardware and release that dynamically as well. So you can scale up your applications and scale them down based on the Loadd because you're developing smaller components. It's much easier to release micro services compared to monolith applications. This means that you can bring new features faster to market and that's a big advantage to have in the modern world.

What is Docker?

Docker is a tool designed to make it easier to build, deploy and run application by containers.

Why Docker?

Before Docker sometime we faced issue like code works in DEV environment but for QA environment it does not work even though we have same code base in each environment. Why such kind of issue industry faced and what is the reason behind it.

  • Dependency version mismatch from one environment to another
  • Library corrupted
  • Software upgrade(DEV env is using jdk8 but QA env has jdk7 so new feature related to jdk will not work in QA env)
How Docker resolve this issue?

Containers allow a developers to package up an application with all of the parts it needs such as libraries and other dependencies and ship it all out as one package.

We can ship one container to all the environment so there will not be a version mismatch issue.

Docker Architecture?

Docker works/occupied memory in host operating system rather than guest operating system.

FROM openjdk:8

What is dispatcher servlet?
  • Dispatcher Servlet is a front controller for Spring web MVC framework.
  • Dispatcher Servlet handles all the request coming to Spring Boot Application.
Who is configuring dispatcher servlet?
  • Spring Web MVC is configuring Dispatcher Servlet.
  • Spring boot starter web has dependency on spring web MVC framework. Spring web MVC has dispatcher servlet in classpath.

What does dispatcher servlet do?
  • Once request comes Dispatcher Servlet find associated controller for that request.
  • It looks for the URI with method and associated controller method.
How does the HelloWorldBean object get converted to JSON?
  • HttpMessageConverters are responsible for JSON conversion from Bean.
  • HttpMessageConverters have dependency on JacksonBean and JacksonBean is used as a default conversion from spring boot.

import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.ControllerAdvice;

import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RestController;
import org.springframework.web.context.request.WebRequest;
import org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.ResponseEntityExceptionHandler;

@ControllerAdvice
@RestController
public class CustomizedResponseEntityExceptionalHandler extends ResponseEntityExceptionHandler {

  @ExceptionHandler(Exception.class)
  public final ResponseEntity<Object> handleAllException(Exception ex, WebRequest request) {
    ExceptionResponse exceptionResponse = new ExceptionResponse(new Date(), ex.getMessage(),
        request.getDescription(false), 500);
    return new ResponseEntity(exceptionResponse, HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
  }
  
  @ExceptionHandler(UserNotFoundException.class)
  public final ResponseEntity<Object> handleUserNotFoundException(Exception ex, WebRequest request) {
    ExceptionResponse exceptionResponse = new ExceptionResponse(new Date(), ex.getMessage(),
        request.getDescription(false), 404);
    return new ResponseEntity(exceptionResponse, HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND);
  }
}

1. What are all the types of Pop up boxes available in JavaScript?

2. What is the difference between an alert box and a confirmation box?

An alert box displays only one button which is the OK button.

But a Confirmation box displays two buttons namely OK and cancel.

3. What is Callback?

A callback is a plain JavaScript function passed to some method as an argument or option. It is a function that is to be executed after another function has finished executing, hence the name ‘call back‘. In JavaScript, functions are objects. Because of this, functions can take functions as arguments, and can be returned by other functions.

4. What is a prompt box?

A prompt box is a box which allows the user to enter input by providing a text box. Label and box will be provided to enter the text or number.

Example
              let inputData = prompt("Hi, Please enter your password again to proceed further!");
              console.log(inputData);
5. What is === operator?

=== is called as strict equality operator which returns true when the two operands are having the same value without any type conversion.

=== it will check type and value, if type will mismatch it will return false

6. Explain the difference between "==" and "==="?

"==" checks only for equality in value whereas "===" is a stricter equality test and returns false if either the value or the type of the two variables are different.

=== it will check type and value, if type will mismatch it will return false

== it will check only value, if type will mismatchand value is same then it will return true false

7. What would be the result of 5+4+"7"?

Since 5 and 4 are integers, they will be added numerically. And since 7 is a string, its concatenation will be done. So the result would be 97.

8. What is an undefined value in JavaScript?

Undefined value means

  • If we have declare variable but not assigned and reading value of that variable then it will return undefined value.
  • If you are using Typescript then editor will not allow you to use variable if it is not declared
9. What is the use of typeof operator?

'typeof' is an operator which is used to return a string description of the variable type.

                obj.name = "Arif";

14. Define event bubbling?

JavaScript allows DOM elements to be nested inside each other. In such a case, if the handler of the child is clicked, the handler of parent will also work as if it were clicked too.

Example
      <!DOCTYPE html>
      <html>
      <head>
        <meta charset="utf-8">
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width">
        <title>Event Bubbling</title>
      </head>
      <body>
        <div id="parent">
          <button id="child">Child</button>
        </div>
        
        <script>
          var parent = document.querySelector('#parent');
          <!-- Add click event on parent div -->
            parent.addEventListener('click', function(){
              console.log("Parent clicked");
            });
          var child = document.querySelector('#child');
          <!-- Add click event on child button -->
            child.addEventListener('click', function(){
              console.log("Child clicked");
            });
        </script>
      </body>

15. Is JavaScript case sensitive? Give an example?

Yes, JavaScript is case sensitive. For example, a function parseInt is not same as the function Parseint.

This means that language keywords, variables, function names, and any other identifiers must always be typed with a consistent capitalization of letters.

16. What boolean operators can be used in JavaScript?

20. How to create a cookie using JavaScript?

The simplest way to create a cookie is to assign a string value to the document.cookie object, which looks like this- 

document.cookie = "key1 = value1; key2 = value2; expires = date";
21. How to read a cookie using JavaScript?

Reading a cookie is just as simple as writing one, because the value of the document.cookie object is the cookie. So you can use this string whenever you want to access the cookie.

  • The document.cookie string will keep a list of name = value pairs separated by semicolons, where name is the name of a cookie and value is its string value.

setState() does not immediately mutate this.state but creates a pending state transition. Accessing this.state after calling this method can potentially return the existing value. There is no guarantee of synchronous operation of calls to setState and calls may be batched for performance gains.

Basic App with Angular
BehaviourSubject & Subject
BehaviourSubject will return the initial value or the current value on Subscription 
var subject = new Rx.BehaviorSubject(0);  // 0 is the initial value

subject.subscribe({
  next: (v) => console.log('observerA: ' + v)  // output initial value, then new values on `next` triggers
});

subject.next(1);  // output new value 1 for 'observer A'
subject.next(2);  // output new value 2 for 'observer A', current value 2 for 'Observer B' on subscription

subject.subscribe({
  next: (v) => console.log('observerB: ' + v)  // output current value 2, then new values on `next` triggers
});

subject.next(3);

        observerA: 0
        observerA: 1
        observerA: 2
        observerB: 2
        observerA: 3
        observerB: 3

Top 10 Rxjs operator

Rxjs operator is not only for Angular. They can be used for javascript and typescript frameworks. But in this section we will see Rxjs operator in Angular specifically.

#10 - of/from

of - it is used to convert object in the form of observable.

from - it is used to convert promise/observable in the form of observable.

Example
  import { Component } from '@angular/core';
  import { Observable, of, from } from 'rxjs';
  
  @Component({
	  selector: 'app-root',
	  templateUrl: './app.component.html',
	  styleUrls: ['./app.component.scss']
  })
  export class AppComponent {
	  title = 'rxjs-angular';
  
	  ngOnInit() {
		  // of operator is used to convert javascript object into the observable
		  const person = {
			  name: 'arif'
		  };
  
		  const person$: Observable<Object> = of(person);
  
		  person$.subscribe(p => console.log(p));
  
		  // from is used to convert promise and observable into the observable
  
		  const employees = [
			  {name: 'xyz1'},
			  {name: 'xyz2'}
		  ];
  
  
		  const promiseOfEmployees: Promise<Object> = Promise.resolve(employees);
		  const promiseOfEmployees$: Observable<Object> = from(promiseOfEmployees);
  
		  promiseOfEmployees$.subscribe(e => console.log(e));
  
		  // convertering oberservable into observertion(it has no uses in real time)
  
		  const person2$: Observable<Object> = from(person$);
  
		  person2$.subscribe(e => console.log(e));
  
	  }
  
  }
#9 - map/tap

map - map operator is used to manipulate the data based on our requirement

tap - tap operator will not allow us to manipulate the data

Example
  import { Component } from '@angular/core';
  import { Observable, of, from } from 'rxjs';
  import { map, tap } from 'rxjs/operators';
  
  @Component({
	  selector: 'app-root',
	  templateUrl: './app.component.html',
	  styleUrls: ['./app.component.scss']
  })
  export class AppComponent {
	  title = 'rxjs-angular';
  
	  ngOnInit() {
		  const source = of('arif');
  
		  // tap operator will now allow to manipulate the data
  
		  source
		  .pipe(tap(name => name.toUpperCase()))
		  .subscribe(data => console.log(data));
		  
  
		  // map operator is used to manipulate the data
		  source
		  .pipe(map(name => name.toUpperCase()))
		  .subscribe(data => console.log(data));
  
	  }
  
  }

In this section and the previous few section we talked a lot about this spring cloud config server the spring cloud config server used to manage all the configuration related to multiple micro services. So here we have multiple micro services and there would be configuration for each of these micro services for different environments. We saw how we can configure the properties put limits service for different environments using this sping cloud config server all that we had to do was to create a few property files with specific naming convention in the GIT repository and commit them in. And then we were able to connect the sping cloud config server to the GIT repository to be able to serve those configuration. We connected the limits service to the spring cloud config server to pick the values from the GIT repository. So let's say here want now to connect another micro service to the spring cloud config server. What would be the steps that would be involved. Number one is you have to create those configuration the GIT repository and commit them in. So if I want to say currency exchange service and I would want to create the configuration for QA I would probably name it as currency hyphen exchange hyphen service hyphen Q8 dot properties and put the property configuration in there and commit it down to the GIT repository. The next thing you do is to connect the currency exchange service to the spring cloud config server. So instead of application dot properties we would rename the configuration file to bootstrap dot properties and put the URI for this sping cloud config. Server those are the only two steps which are in involved. Once you have spring cloud config server installed connecting a new Micro serviceto it is a cakewalk. The great thing about the spring cloud config server is now all application configuration is in one place it's inside the GIT repository. Once you restrict the access to the GIT repository all the application configuration is at one place and it's also very secure. One of the things that we saw was we had to restart the limits service to pick up the changes in configuration from the GIT repository. And that becomes even more problem where there are multiple instances of the Limits service. The reason why we called the limits service Micro service because we would want to be able to deploy to the cloud and would want to be able to have multiple instances of it running and we would want these instances all instances to pick up the configuration changes as soon as they are available in the GIT repository. And we would want to have a easy way of doing that. That's one thing we would look at in a later section on sping cloud config server. Let's put a pause on the discussion on sping cloud config server here and move into other important problems related to micro services We will come back to spring cloud config server when we would talk about using spring cloud bus to make sure that all the changes all the configuration changes that are done through the GIT repository are automatically reflected in the applications.

    Map<String, String> uriVariables = new HashMap<>();
    uriVariables.put("from", from);
    uriVariables.put("to", to);
      ResponseEntity<CurrencyConversionBean> responseEntity = new RestTemplate().getForEntity("http://localhost:8000/currency-exchange/from/{from}/to/{to}", CurrencyConversionBean.class, uriVariables);

      response2.setPort(response.getPort());
      return response2;
  }
}

blogData: In the previous step we configured ribbon we made ribbon distributed the load between two instances of the currency exchange service. So what ever service calls are coming from the currency calculation service. We were able to use ribbon and distribute them between the currency exchange service one and two which were running on ports eight thousand and eight thousand one respectively. Let's assume that I would start up another instance of the currency exchange service let's call it currency exchange service 3 and launch it up on eight thousand two will ribbon be able to distribute the load. To it with things as they stand right now. Think about it thing is if I would want ribbon to distribute the load to the new server I would need to add it to the configuration. So I would need to change my application configuration whenever a new server is created. And that's not really good. What I would want to be able to do is based on the load I would want to be able to increase and decrease the number of instances of these services. So I would want to be able to dynamically increase the currency exchange services or decrease them if I have to keep on changing the configuration of currency calculations service based on how many currency exchange services are active right. Then it becomes very very difficult maintenance headache. That's where the name services come in. If the currency exchange service is running on a URL xyz you don't want to hardcoded on the currency calculation service because there might be a new instance of the currency exchange service coming up or the existing instance might be going down and things like that rather than that we have something called namings server. All the instances of all micro services would register with the naming server. Whenever an instance of a micro service comes up it would register itself Eureka naming service this is called Service registration. And whenever a service wants to talk to another service let's said the currency calculation Service wants to talk to the currency exchange service what would it do. It would talk to the name server and it would ask the name server what are the instances of the currency exchange service that are currently running. This is called. Service discovery. So the currency calculation Service is asking for the location of the currency exchange service the instances of currency exchange service that is called service discovery. The two important features of the naming server are service registration and service discovery at startup of every application they would register with the naming server and whenever they want details of another micro service they would a service discovery they'll say I want the details of service X Y Z. Can you give me the details in the next step. We would set up a naming server and have currency calculation service and the currency exchange service connect to that.

blogData:
In this step let's take a pause and take a quick review of what we have been doing until now.

We started with creating a couple of Micro services currency calculation service and currency exchange service currency calculation service is a consumer of the currency exchange service.

When we started off we had a direct URL connection between the currency calculation service and the currency exchange service.

So if we have other currency exchange services which are coming up the currency calculation service but not able to talk to them and to be able to get load balancing the introduced ribbon. Before that we added feign the currency calculation service to make it easy to call the rest services from currency exchange service with feign writing client services for restfull webservices becomes very easy.

After that we added ribbon and we load balance between two instances of the currency exchange service so all the calls that were coming in from the currency calculation service were distributed between two instances of the currency exchange service the way we achieve that is by hard coding the URLs of the currency exchange service in the application dot properties of the currency conversion service we thought that that's not good enough.

And we introduced namings server we connected. Currency calculation service. And the currency exchange service to the naming server. And what we did is instead of hard coding the values are hard coading the URLs of the currency exchange. service with the currency calculation service we said talk to the naming server and get the URLs of the currency exchange service in the last step we were able to dynamically bring up and send down the currency exchange. services if there were four currency exchange services which were alive then we were distributing the load between them. If two of them are brought down the remaining two are the ones which would handle all the requests we were able to dynamically bring up services bring them down without causing a problem to the consumers without causing a problem to the currency calculation service. This is what is needed in the world of micro services in the world of micro services. There are so many small services which are talking to each other that we would want to be able to bring new instances of them take all the instances down without causing a problem to any of the other consumers. And that what we have set up between the currency calculation service and the currency exchange service. and the tools we used to be able to do that are A the naming server and B. Ribbon C is feign naming server is the one which offers registration that service registration and service discovery functionality ribbon provides the client side load balancing facilities so it enables client calculation service to distribute the load between multiple service providers and we used feign to make sure that the code that we write inside the currency calculation service to call the currency exchange. Service is very simple. In the subsequent steps we would shift our attention to its monitoring and troubleshooting when we have multiple micro services. In the section on micro services until now we have created three simple micro services currency calculation service the currency exchange service and the limits Service typically in a micro services architecture you'd have 100 of micro services that are talking to each other and there are common features that we would need to implement for all these micro services.

You would want to make sure that every call to every micro service is authenticated. A check is done on the authorization whether the user has the right permissions. You also want to implement things like rate limit for a specific client.

You would only want to allow certain number of calls per hour or per day they might be limits like that present you'd want all these micro services to be fault tolerant if there is a service that I am depended on and it's not up I should be able to give some default response back and in a typical micro service environment they should also be some kind of service aggregation that should be provided.

Let's say there is an external consumer who wants to call 15 different services as part of one process. It's better to aggregate those 15 services and provide one service call for the external consumer. So these are kinds of features that are common across all the micro services and these are features which are implemented at the level of API gateways instead of allowing micro services to call each other directly what we will do is we would make all the calls go through a API gateway and the API gateway would take care of providing common features like authentication making sure that all service calls are logged making sure that the rate limits are at the two and making sure that these services are fault. tolerence. The API gateways can also provide aggregation services around multiple services because all calls get routed through the API gateways it a gateways. Introduction
Eureka discovery service also refers to Spring Cloud Netflix Eureka. Netflix build Eureka discovery server for there on needs and until now they actively using. Later Netflix Eureka became the part of Spring cloud. Now it is used world wide.
What does Eureka do?

Lets suppose we have Users Service Microservice and Client App. To send the request from client to User service we need to know the domain name of the user microservice. After getting URL/domain name we can call the user service. Now think if we need to scale up the User Microservice, means we have multiple instance(domain name) of user service then how we can call from client side.
Setup Eureka Server from start.spring.io
Start a Eureka Service Registry
You first need a Eureka Service registry. You can use Spring Cloud’s @EnableEurekaServer to stand up a registry with which other applications can communicate. This is a regular Spring Boot application with one annotation (@EnableEurekaServer) added to enable the service registry.

PhotoAppEurekaDiscoveryServiceApplication.java

package com.way2p.PhotoAppEurekaDiscoveryService;

import org.springframework.boot.SpringApplication;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.SpringBootApplication;
import org.springframework.cloud.netflix.eureka.server.EnableEurekaServer;

@SpringBootApplication
@EnableEurekaServer
public class PhotoAppEurekaDiscoveryServiceApplication {

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    SpringApplication.run(PhotoAppEurekaDiscoveryServiceApplication.class, args);
  }

}
